results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 - Blue
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 – Blue was broadcast as the fifth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Adem Jaffers (Tekno Mandala), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), Dale Nasonand Kim Bounds (abcTVxyz), Dale Nason and Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), 1x4x9 (Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson), ABCTVXYZ, Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton) and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 - Blue is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Voyager [game trailer]
results.brief_description: In a faraway world lived two clans, Dezminus and Akai. Their only connection was a trade route, trading Dezminus’ ores for Akai’s wheat. But one day Dezminus’s food supplies stopped coming. So Dezminus decided to declare war and conquer the Clan of Akai. So they sent a warship to declare war on Akai. The captain of that vessel was…you.

results.title: Bins vs. Rubbish [game trailer]
results.creator_credit: Auburn Primary School, Ari Kritzerseferi, Harry Dempsey, Jordan Trieu and Luc Thompson
results.brief_description:
A short excerpt from a computer game created for the 2010 ‘Screen It’ competition. This fun strategy game lets you dodge, catch and shoot rubbish. The message is to stop littering, as it can hurt animals and increase global warming.

This trailer illustrates how the game is played.

results.title: Kiru umi no yoni / Cutting like the ocean
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
One of Callas’ most personally confronting works, it is made up of six parts, and utilises the image of a knife slicing horizontally through the pictorial screen as its central and linking motif. Its starting point was an installation by Callas which incorporated a photograph from the 1920s of two severed heads belonging to a male and female of an indigenous tribe in Formosa (Taiwan). At once horrific and enigmatic, this image forms a potent metaphor for Japan’s pre-Second World War imperial past. The significance of the work is not confined to Japan alone - it also offers a kind of mirror with which to face atrocities committed in colonial Australia.

Produced with the assistance of the Australian Film Commission.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Birthday boy
results.creator_credit: AFTRS, Andrew Gregory and Sejong Park
results.brief_description: Korea 1951 - little Manuk is playing on the streets of his village and dreaming of life at the front where his father is a soldier. He returns home to find a parcel on the doorstep and, thinking it is a birthday present, he opens it. But its contents will change his life.

results.title: Punching keys
results.creator_credit: Sally Ingleton and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: A biting dramatisation of the effects of the new technology in deskilling the female office workforce, alienating women from the products of their labour, and rendering them replaceable by cheaper labour overseas. Cast includes a young Gina Riley.

results.title: Earthquake in Turkey
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @matemusic1's TikTok post
results.brief_description: The dramatic collapse of a building in the aftermath of the recent earthquake that devestated Turkey and Syria - or is it? While posted alongside other videos of the event, this one turns out to be a building losing its scaffolding in Japan several years ago. Unlike traditional news media where journalists are trained to check their facts, social media responds to disasters immediately but randomly. On the upside, some people who were trapped in collapsed buildings were able to post about their situation, alerting friends, family and rescuers to come to their aid. This video was removed a couple of days after being posted.
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

The collapse of a building during the recent earthquake that devastated Turkey and Syria – or is it?

While posted alongside other videos of the event, this one is a building in Japan losing its scaffolding several years ago. Unlike traditional news media, where journalists are trained to check their facts, social media responses to disasters may be immediate but they can also be inaccurate. On the upside, some people who were trapped in collapsed buildings in the earthquake used social media to alert friends, family and rescuers to come to their aid. This video was removed a couple of days after being posted.
description_for_label:
The collapse of a building during the recent earthquake that devastated Turkey and Syria – or is it?

While posted alongside other videos of the event, this one is a building in Japan losing its scaffolding several years ago. Unlike traditional news media, where journalists are trained to check their facts, social media responses to disasters may be immediate but they can also be inaccurate. On the upside, some people who were trapped in collapsed buildings in the earthquake used social media to alert friends, family and rescuers to come to their aid. This video was removed a couple of days after being posted.

results.title: Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey documentary poster
results.brief_description: Poster for the documentary ‘Theremin: An Electronic Odyssey.’ This documentary explores the life of Leon Theremin, the inventor of an electronic synthesizer called the theremin, which uses motion to produce a sliding ethereal sound. After creating the instrument, Theremin is kidnapped by the KGB to work on inventions and surveillance technology. During his absence, the theremin becomes a popular instrument in film scores and through the performances of Clara Rockmore. In 1991, Theremin finally returns to the United States after his release.
